Authors:
Kang-Li Zhu, Xuming Zhou, Shixia Xu, Di Sun, Kaiya Zhou,
Guang Yang
Title:
The loss and adaptive evolution of taste genes in
cetaceans
Keywords:
Keywords: Cetacean; Taste genes; Pseudogenization;
Adaptive evolution
Abstract:
Background: Five basic taste modalities, i.e. sour, sweet,
bitter, salt and umami, could be distinguished by humans and are
fundamental for physical and ecological adaptations in mammals.
Currently, although molecular genetics of these taste receptor genes has
been conducted in terrestrial mammals, little is known about the
evolution and adaptation of these genes in marine mammals. As the
representatives of secondary aquatic mammals, cetaceans have grasped the
evolutionistsâ attraction to investigate their mysterious evolutionary
history. For this reason, we make a systematic survey on major lineages
of cetaceans including representative toothed and baleen whales to
investigate the evolution of the these five basic taste modalities.
Resultsï¼Here, all five basic taste modalities: sour, sweet, bitter,
salt and umami tastes were investigated in cetaceans. The sequence
characteristics and evolutionary analyses suggested that nearly all
cetaceans have lost all taste modalities except for salt. Interestingly,
the time estimated for these pseudogenization events occurred varied
among taste genes, however, overall these times are close to the tMRCA
(the time to the most recent common ancestor) of toothed and baleen
whales. Conclusions: This is the first time to clarify the five basic
taste modalities in marine mammals. Our research indicated that
cetaceans have lost four basic taste modalities including sour, sweet,
umami, and major of bitter taste. The transition from land to water at
approximately 52.5 Mya and subsequent great changes in feeding behavior
and circumstances they lived in might contribute to the loss of the four
tastes. The integrity of salt taste receptor genes in all cetaceans
studied here, may owe to its function in Na+ reabsorbing, which is key
to osmoregulation in aquatic adaptation.
